summary: The Grimm fairy tale gets a Technicolor treatment in Disney's first animated feature. Jealous of Snow White's beauty, the wicked queen orders the murder of her innocent stepdaughter, but later discovers that Snow White is still alive and hiding in a cottage with seven friendly little miners. Disguising herself as a hag, the queen brings a poisoned apple to Snow White, who falls into a death-like sleep that can be broken only by a kiss from the prince.

reviews.content: Walt Disney had a very strong heart, and he shared his love with everyone around him based on the stories that he made during his time. SNOW WHITE AND THE SEVEN DWARFS was one of those stories, and since then, it has become a legendary work of art that continues to inspire every generation of movie goers around the world. I am truly blessed to watch this movie over and over again. It has so much love and so much happiness it just makes you want to cry every time you watch it.
The greatest 01 hour: and 20 minutes ever!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Starring the cast mates that will be missed dearly!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

The CLASSIC.  The LEFT would NEVER allow it now... too many transgressions.  Insensitive to dwarfs, etc.  Remember my parents taking me to see this at a drive-in theater when I was very young.  Why, I'm not sure, since it was made in 1937!  
giving it max 5 RT stars.

this movie has so little actual content its kinda funny. Honestly there is very little in this movie that could be considered actual scenes. Most of the movie is padded with tediously dragged out songs. Honestly though I can't really hate this film since there isn't much to hate here.

Disney's original classic at its finest, instrumental to the world of magic, and family fun, friendly excitement. The Disney masterpiece developed a princess that lived on forever and allowed even little boys and girls enjoy the excitement in this film. The dwarfs bring on a fun, comical aspect, and a heroic ending. With a prince that steps in to open up the day full of love and excitement. This is one masterpiece that you could live on watching multiple times, and still enjoy the fun and excitement of this film from years and years later.

Walt Disney truly started something spectacular 85 years later and this remains his crowning achievement setting the bar for all animated movies to come, in fact it almost didn't get made because of a $1.5 million venture but his tenacity proved otherwise thanks to his wife Most of the animators credited in “Snow White” are men, but the majority of inkers and painters were women Hundreds of women were employed in the Ink and Paint department at Disney Even though hours were long, and it was a rigorous, thankless job But it was an essential part of helping “Snow White” reach the screen This is based on the 1812 German fairy tale published by the Brothers Grimm, remains a favorite with a new generation of fans even though the source material was much darker in nature Having lost both of her parents as a child, Snow White is a princess living with her miserable stepmother, the Queen, who forces Snow White to become a maid in her own castle After the Queen’s magic mirror informs her that Snow White is the fairest one of all, everything changes The Queen orders her huntsman to kill Snow White, but he can’t bring himself to do it and encourages her to run away for her own safety Snow White is surrounded by caring woodland animals and befriends seven dwarves stumbling upon their cottage Thankfully this film won over audiences and critics while also grossing $418 million thanks to reissues, video games, theme park rides and even a Broadway show continue the story's massive popularity This did inspire Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to produce the brilliant fantasy film, “The Wizard of Oz” in 1939 and even Charlie Chaplin gave it a big thumbs up In 1989, the United States Library of Congress even recognized “Snow White” as “culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant” and selected it as one of the first 25 films for preservation in the National Film Registry as well as the American Film Institute ranking it as the 49th greatest film of all time and also tabbed it as the greatest American animated film It was something else they actually had audiences cry at an animated feature as opposed to real people Snow White is a nice character even though the voice actress sounds very Betty Boop-ish The prince has no personality and very little lines The Queen is standard being filled with vanity but her design is impressive and even turning into the old hag is very balsy given all the scary imagery they inserted in here The Dwarfs are funny and easy to distinguish and make the charm of the film come alive Grumpy in particular has to learn to warm up to Snow White I am glad though they featured more of the characters in Kingdom Hearts video games The animation is stellar with its artistry and backgrounds, the songs are memorable, the villain is one of the most iconic in Disney history, the comedy works, and the ending is one of the finest for a happily ever after making the viewing worth it Despite a short running time Walt Disney succeeded in more ways than one for kids and adults of all ages Happily ever after is ok for us to still believe in it thanks to the simple storytelling
Snow White is a wonderful film that gets boring at times, but is still a timeless work of art, with beautiful animation, captivating characters and one of the most memorable villains of all time.
Happy 85th Anniversary to this masterpiece! 🎊🥳👏
I think this is the first movie I ever say. I don't know whether they still ran it in the cinema almost 30 years later. What I do know is that it was pretty scary.
The one that started it all. True disney classic before they sold their souls and went woke.

Watched this classic animated film with my family, and the kids were engrossed, and me and my wife had a few laughs at the funny scenes!

At its surface, the story of this fairy tale is simplistic and kind of silly, but upon reflection this portrays how an obsession (such as obsession in beauty) can result in evil, how love can make us good and overcome evil, and how beautiful it is of a man and a woman to trust, long for, and love each other.

not only is this the movie that got the animated movie train rolling. but is has dazzling animation, lovable characters, great songs, and this movie single handedly proves that any dream can become reality!
It's the firist disney moviee!! Very cool and the cartoon is so cute, and the villain(evil queen) is very memorable. But don't have that big WOW, like the others disney movies.
Timeless, and the first of its kind. A real treasure.
Snow White is my favorite Disney princess
'The one that started it all' is a good adaptation of the original fairy tale by the brothers Grimm, but today it stumbles mainly because of the old-fashioned animation and the zeitgeist.
This is a great Disney classic. Which is still a joy to watch even this day. All of the other spin offs would not have happened without this classic movie.

It's successors in the Disney pantheon (and certainly in the full landscape of animation) have achieved grander and greater things, but Snow White is still worthy of its landmark status as the first feature-length animated film ever produced.
Beautiful animation, semi-entertaining story.

One of the biggest crowning achievement that was once no such thing as Animated Films at the time and would be impossible to do it until Walt Disney wasn't afraid to that on that challenge. Beautiful Animation and Music, and like-able characters.

A classic that was great for its time. The animation quality, colour, characters with personality, depth to the scenery, and soundtrack were all well done and a major advancement. However, Snow White is only 14, and the character represents the stereotypical woman back then, which is dodgy nowadays. The human characters were also animated more poorly than the animals, dwarfs, and witch, with Snow White and the prince looking like fatty blobs with no definition to their arms, necks, and faces. Furthermore, the plot was simplistic, the pacing dragged, and some of the words in the songs were inaudible. There also could have been more characters since the hunter played barely any role and the queen seemed to be surrounded by nobody.

An interesting film to rewatch as it was the 1st theatrically released animated feature. And as an animated film it still holds. Granted the evolution in the way of storytelling and style of animation have pulled this back a bit. But it shall remain as one of the most precious films of all time.
The Movie that launched a Dynasty! Timeless and ground breaking.

When Disney studios decided to make a feature length cartoon there were grave doubts about such a venture. This movie was the first of its kind and many pundits doubted the sense of throwing so much money at a project they thought had no audience.
The movie proofed that the project was visionary. When Snow White are the

From 1937 when it was first released to where it's at now Snow Whit and the seven dwarfs has stood the test of time and is a beautiful emotion hallmark of a movie that is everything Disney should be.  Relying entirely on emotion to tell the story and directed by David Hand Snow White its still a worthy masterpiece that deserves to be watched.  With breathtaking animation dark moments  and memorable songs there is something for everyone in this one of a kind film.  I still think Mary Poppins is the definitive Disney masterpiece and Fantasia comes in second Snow White is in my top five favorite Disney films.

Snow White is the sweetest, and original, Disney princess.  Girls nowadays like their princesses and movie idols with a little edge, but considering this was made in 1937, it's still timeless and chock full of the key ingredients to Disney's recipe for success:  romance, mystery, mild peril, and. music.  

Snow White has it all, and it's a testament to the original Walt Disney animators that the traditional, hand-drawn animation can still evoke so much terror (the bulging eyes that creep out of the enchanted forest, or the menacing look of the two vultures), pathos (the sight of Snow White's outstretched hand after eating the apple) and tenderness (the dwarfs mourning Snow White's apparent death).  Seven decades have passed and this original wicked Queen is still the scariest of the Disney villians, and Snow White quite possibly the fairest of them all.
Of course it needs credit for the impact it made on filmography, but watching it now is somewhat underwhelming.

Snow White is the original. Disney's reign of animated films begins with this beautiful piece of art. Some of the musical elements have aged a bit, but years and years later this holds up fantastically. The story is pretty quick and simple, sure. That's the charm to me, the humble origins of Disney on full showcase. The characters are great and fun to watch on screen, the villain is an actual villain, and the environments and sets are beautifully drawn. 

I do think this film would have benefited more from a slightly longer run time. However, given the time period and the financial situation Walt Disney was dealing with to produce this; it works just fine. Short and Sweet. Just like Happy the Dwarf.

The movie that started it all, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs' beautiful animation, memorable characters, great songs and combination of funny, sad and downright scary* moments mean that, even all these years later, the Disney Animated Canon's first entry - and the studio's first full-length feature film - still does a remarkable job standing the test of time. 
*Though there will be no Disney movie scarier than Pinocchio as far as I'm concerned. Good God, man, that movie was DARK

While you can not deny the historical importance of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, (It is the first full length color animated motion picture and was the highest grossing film of all time until Gone with the Wind came along two years later) it really doesn't hold up to modern audiences. The outdated depiction of a woman's role in society is most prominent. The songs are great and mostly timeless, however, with the exception of two ("Wishing Well" and "Someday My Prince will Come") they add nothing meaningful to the story as the music should in a musical. Plus the two mentioned are redundant, as they both show Snow White's desire for her prince. I love the Dwarfs! Grumpy is the only character with a story arc in the movie. Snow White's voice is annoying to me, Walt Disney even stated that he wished he could have re-recorded the voice actress but ran out of money. If you are curious, check it out

One thing is for sure, that this is not "The Greatest Animated Film Of All Time". I mean, it definitely used to be but just for 3 years, until the second Disney animated movie came out. I'm adding at least half a star because of the historical significance of this movie, and another half for the songs that became universally recognizable. This movie is a prodigy for the time, but for today's standards it's quite boring: dated dialogue, dull color palette ranging from browns to greys, and for more than half of the movie nothing happens. Most of the characterization is reserved to the dwarfs, while the "humans" of the story are left quite undeveloped.

However, we owe so much to this movie that it would be improvident to bash it too much. Thanks Walt!

The Walt Disney classic that started it all! Snow white may be a bit generic by today's standards but paved the way for future Disney princesses the dwarfs each have their own Lovable personalities however there are some seriously Dark/frightening scenes. the witch is one of Disney's scariest characters one that original 1930s audiences found quite disturbing, Animation was groundbreaking at the time of release being the first full length animated film and a staple in cinema history
The classic animation that began it all.  Still a must see favorite for kids.   The film that began all that Disney Magic with magic right from the start.

Archie’s review: “How long does this movie take? My favourite little man is Doc. There’s an old woman that lives in a castle. Look at those birds!! I don’t like the bad old lady. Why are the animals just outside standing in the rain? Oh, it’s this guy again. I don’t even know his name (the prince). I liked the part of the old lady falling off the cliff and that she’s gone forever.” 🍎

I'm just gonna quote what my dvd case says for the movie. "The One That Started It All" and "The Movie That Defined Animation" is the perfect way to describe this movie, a groundbreaker. Despite that, this movie has some major problems, but again it can partially be looked past for the first animated film ever. One, it can be very boring and has a lot of filler, which can be very hard to watch sometimes. For example, the seven dwarfs take 12 minutes out of the film to wash themselves for food. Ummmm I don't want to see that in a film. The Evil Queen is kind of a boring villain, and before the seven dwarfs show up, the movie is kind of unbearable. That and Snow White the character is a little boring and Grumpy is annoying, but that's more for the times, I can look past that. Another kind of problem is that this movie is kind of only drive by emotion. Like there's really no logic here, and I don't mind that for a good stretch of a movie, but not the entire thing. With all it that said, this movie has some really good things in it. The animation is stellar, especially for the time (I believe that the movie came out in 1937, and that's crazy to think about). The fairytale that they chose is nice and the story is told well enough. This movie has a lot of creepy imagery, the highlights being the forest and the queens transformation to the witch. The best thing in this movie is the seven dwarfs, and that's a lot more fun to watch then Snow White cleaning….So, I guess this is a movie that I more respect then I actually like, but with the combination of the respect I have for it and the things I do like about it, it did just enough to call it a good film, at least for me. I would say watch it, but let's face it, you've already have. But I would say rewatch this true groundbreaker of a film, you won't regret it!

This movie is EXTREMELY important in the history of film, something inevidable and inarguable. But it's such a dated film that it will bore you to tears, I'm sorry. It is a very short movie, but boy do you feel every second of it. The plot moves so slowly, the techniques have aged with the human characters, and the songs aside from 'Heigh Ho' are pretty forgettable. It's a decent kids movie and important to note as the grand opening of Disney, but it's nothing worth for adults.

Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs is to animation what Superman (1978) is to the superhero genre, and what Stagecoach (1939) is to the western. It technically wasn't the first animated feature made (though it *was* the first feature length traditionally animated film), but it showed that it was possible for a cartoon to do more than simply make someone laugh, and showed that animation was truly an art form in its own right. Snow White was the first of what is now known as the Disney Animated Features canon, and was the cornerstone of the animated empire that would be created in its wake. A massive critical and commercial success at the time of its release, adjusted for inflation Snow White remains the highest grossing animated film of all time, and one of the highest grossing films in history.

The film itself, however, has not quite aged as well as its indisputable influence. Though the film is certainly beautiful, and certainly no expense was spared on its visuals, which were unparalleled for the time (save perhaps by the Fleischer studios), the animation is somewhat crude at times, and small errors can be seen here and there. The story itself is fairly loose, as the film feels more like an overlong Silly Symphony, rather than a coherent film. However, there's no denying that the film does get you to truly feel for its title character, and the character evolution of Grumpy was unlike anything seen in a cartoon at the time. The music is also beautiful, and would introduce several memorable songs, such as "Whistle while you Work," "One Song," "Heigh-ho," and of course the immortal "Someday My Prince Will Come."
Only listen to the critics and 5 star audience reviews, ignore everyone else. It's a great movie. "Doesn't measure up to today's standards". Yeah no shit, morons, it was released in 1937
Charming, beautiful and magical, there are not enough words to express the improbability of ‘Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs'.
One of my favorite Disney movies of all time is perfect

The nostalgia of this film is enough to make adults adore it, but for modern day first time viewers, I feel that the story is rushed. The female lead does rely on a male hero, but for a film of this time period that is expected, but for these reasons the film cannot have five stars. Even though the whimsical, dreamy animation sequences do make for a delightful film.
Will always be one of the best Disney films around, beautiful and fun

I don't care if someone tells me, that I'm too old for Disney. To my surprise, I actually loved the movie very much, because it had so many funny scenes with the dwarfs and the woodland creatures. Even though it was kinda creepy at times, I overall liked this classic!

Attempting to go through Walt Disney Animation Studios films, watching one a week. This is where it starts and though I liked it as a kid, it doesn't hold up that well. Some of the songs are memorable, the animation style is good for its time, and there are fun scenes with the dwarfs. The love story at the center is really lame though.
This movie didn't age very well.
It's just a little weird and it wasn't as strong or as memorable. 4.7/10, C-

The nostalgia of this film is enough to make adults adore it, but for modern day first time viewers, I feel that the story is rushed. The female lead does rely on a male hero, but for a film of this time period that is expected, but for these reasons the film cannot have five stars. Even though the whimsical, dreamy animation sequences do make for a delightful film.

For such an old film, this one is a good one.

The one that started it all. 
Look, I appreciate that this was the first ever full-length animated film by Walt Disney himself, and that a lot of talented artists worked on it, but to be completely honest. I didn't like it that much. Now, that doesn't mean it's bad, the animation's stunning, same for the visuals, and some of the characters were good, but what I thought were the first 40 minutes of the film, only turned out to be just 15 minutes. The pacing feels EXTREMELY Slow, and for an hour and a half-long film, it felt like it was 3 hours long instead. And another thing that I'd like to pinpoint is that the ending was a bit... Meh. The prince arrives, and kisses Snow White, The End. Come on, it'd be more interesting for him to at least fight the Evil Queen. A little more screen time wouldn't hurt... That being said, the film's slow pacing is the thing that bothers me the most. But given the excuse that this was Disney's first ever animated film, I'll forgive them that.
Really showcases the abilities of the animators - and still got a few pretty scary moments!

After not watching this movie for MANY years, I'm impressed. A little misogynistic, but mostly in a way that makes men look bad, so I'm okay with it (XD). The animation is still stunning; I mean the gems SHINE!! The animals are adorable, and the soundtrack is perfectly fitting of the action (a la Peter and the Wolf). Overall, I enjoyed it much more than I remembered. Just wonderful!
It's folky, the art style is compelling, and it's a beautiful beginning to the Disney animation legacy.
I am in aw every time I watch this movie. I still don't know how they made this incredible animated movie in 1937.

I'm not going to judge this movie based on how revolutionary it was, so ignoring that- this movie is kinda so-so. The entire movie is just 84 minutes of fluff, but with a little charm and love added to it as opposed to modern Disney movies with absolutely NO love like Moana, CGI Lion king, and Wreck it Ralph 2. Pretty good as a Disney film especially by today's standards.
I absolutely LOVE this film.
Greatest old film animation.
Beautiful animation, catchy songs and timeless to all but the most cynical of us.
A beautiful classic.
well, great quality for a 1937 cartoon, a bit boring script but it's cool. very cool characters that match the film.

This animated Disney classic was great. The entire cast and crew did an excellent job on this movie. The plot to the movie was entertaining and pretty humorous. It's not one of my favorite movies of all time, but it's a movie an entire family would enjoy. If you haven't seen this classic movie yet, check it out sometime. It's a must see.

This Movie, is a CLASSIC, the lovely animation the cute protagonist, make this movie, the base of the animation of today that everyone love

Works great for Disney's first animated film, but the story? The prince kisses Snow White DEAD, in any world is this seen as normal?
The classic that would start an era of Disney animation. You go, girl!

Snow white is my absolute least favorite Disney princess, so my bias is going to show a little bit here. She is the first Disney princess and we love that for her, but she's also so incredibly dim and air-headed. WHO EATS AN APPLE AFTER BEING TOLD IT'S MAGIC? FROM A RANDOM STRANGER? No. Her voice is almost unbearably high, and don't even get me started on the prince. I like the conspiracy theory that when the prince kissed Snow they both died, and the castle they go to is heaven, but that's it

Began screening it before letting kids watch and not interested. Barely got 1 minute into it. the first scene is queen talking to her mirror summoning up the spirit she wants to talk to. not interested in witchcraft thanks
This movie is a very average fairy tale. It's theme and character change throughout was not good, but what saved it was it's interesting and fun characters.
Disney's take on the classic tale, still holds up as one of the best. The dwarfs do still the show and your heart. This story is over 100 years old and I don't see it going away anytime soon.

A charming foray into Disney's animated vault.

Walt Disney forever changed cinema by creating the first feature length animated film with his classic family fantasy picture Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937). David Hand's direction is remarkable as he delightfully takes us from one pleasant encounter to another with a blissful, naive, Summer day vibe to Snow White. Everything is bright and cheerful like the vibrant soft pastel color palette for Snow White. 

I like the quaint production design. All the lush greens, pops of red, and dousings of blue are still beautiful to behold. Hand has a unique vision for Snow White to feel like a German folk tale like the Brothers Grimm fairytale it was based on originally. The Germanic influence from Virginia Lockwood's costume designs to the traditional yodeling music is apparent and appreciated. Snow White just simply looks great, especially when you compare it to the animated features at the time. The animation is fluid and soft with tons of moving animals and characters all on top of gorgeous background art. You cannot beat hand drawn animation as Snow White still looks stunning 80 years later.

Paul J. Smith, Frank Churchill, Leigh Harline's score is fantastic for Snow White. All the songs are so memorable and catchy that by the end of them, you are singing along. The characters are very likable with the silly dwarfs with their seven distinct personalities: Doc, Grumpy, Happy, Sleepy, Sneezy, Bashful, and Dopey. It's incredible how Disney changed how we see animated films as family movies with a single blow of 83 entertaining minutes of Snow White hanging out with her 7 new friends. Bill Melendez' editing is swift and surreal like you are watching someone else's dream play out. His soft cuts and fade out edits are really neat to see. 

Adriana Caselotti's iconic soft voice for Snow White is very fun and innocent. She's playful with the dwarfs and has a distinct high pitch that I hope you don't find irritating because she's clearly having a lot of fun with her lead role. Likewise, Lucille La Verne is killer as The Evil Queen and Witch. Her iconic disgust for Snow White is very entertaining. Moroni Olsen is excellent as the blunt Magic Mirror. His deep voice is so engaging and mysterious. He adds a layer of whimsy and mystery to Snow White that I always liked. The entire cast of dwarfs is fun, especially Pinto Colvig as Grumpy and Sleepy. Roy Atwell's stuttering and kind Doc is wonderful. Otis Harlan is such a joyous Happy. Scotty Mattraw is an adorable Bashful. Billy Gilbert goes all out as the loud Sneezy. Eddie Collins is fun as Dopey. Harry Stockwell is solid as the prince with the fun musicals numbers mostly going to the dwarfs.

In all, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs makes you want to go on a fantasy adventure to find your true love, even if you only meet them for a magical moment!

Amazing movie. My favorite when I was a child and even now still great. Typical Disney classic, first Disney movie ever and a must-see. Entertaining from the beginning to the end with a solid story and good characters. Each dwarf has its own personality. Perfect escapist movie. With the old music and style it has an escapist, otherworldly quality while still being timeless.

AFI 100 Greatest Films - #49: Not the most exciting plot by today's standards but has also served as the template for countless narratives in the last 80+ years, and deserves respect for that alone. Phrases such as "Mirror, mirror, on the wall..." and songs like "Whistle While We Work" are as easily recognizable today, if not more so, than I imagine they were in 1937. It is fun to imagine what Walt envisioned his company becoming with the release of his first full length feature, as it can now be argued that no company, or person, has contributed more to the nature of modern entertainment as we know it.
is one of the best animations at disney and perhaps the best known to all
Great classic movie.
The plot is fine, the characters are fine, the songs are fine, this movie is just fine.

The first time I watched Snow White was when I was just about one to two years old. Looking back on how this film changed the course of cinema back in the 1930s makes for a wonderful experience. Watching it now makes you feel like it's 1937 all over again.
I liked it. My daughter loved it. Time well spent.

Disney set themselves a tough act to follow with their first-ever animated feature. An ambitious blend of wacky, stylized cartoon action and smooth, roto-scoped realism, Snow White still serves as a lovely slice of bright, cheery, kid-geared fantasy. Just seeing the whole thing through to the finish line was a significant achievement, amidst all the mainstream doubts and staggering financial risks. But it also stands tall on its own merits, from the bold, unforgettable character designs to the lasting, catchy musical interludes. I'm not sure the studio has ever matched this soundtrack, actually, both in terms of staying power and sheer sing-along-ability.

A few unsightly seams might show - clumsy little tricks to avoid the difficult camera angles and puzzling plot machinations to trim troublesome characters (which explains why the charming prince disappears for most of the film) - but animators were literally flying by the seat of their pants here, experimenting on-stage to test the viability of their chosen medium. I could nitpick about a whole lot of small items, but in a broad sense, it's the rare film that can still easily captivate a willing audience after eighty-plus years in the can. That alone is an incredible testament to the dedication, tenacity and enduring skill of the whole team, and the quality of the finished product. Not perfect - in fact, this team would drastically improve the formula in subsequent efforts - but quite a first step.

The classic that started it all. The one that helped build an empire. "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" might be short for some, but you can't deny it's impact on the animation world. It's crisps and beautiful animation still holds up to this day. Without the success of this film, cartoons will never be the same or big as they are now.
I liked this in Gremlins.
A true Disney classic!

I recognize the artistry and imagination that went into creating Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. At a time when animation was tedious and time-consuming, to cobble together an 83-minute film that looks this good is astounding. I also love the music in this film, because it constantly gets stuck in my head (even though Adriana Caselotti’s voice as Snow White can be a little ear-piercing.) I think where this movie always underwhelms me is the story. There aren’t strong character motivations for most of the things that people do in Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, and none of the characters are developed in any fashion. In fact, they spend more time on the dwarfs goofing off than on any backstory for Snow White or the dwarfs themselves. Sure, there are some funny things in all that singing and playing around, but I could see a better use for the screen-time. The plot is what became the cliché of classic Disney princess films. Of course, Snow White gets a little extra credit for doing it first and setting the standard for what would come out of Disney animation for decades. I simply do not get much enjoyment from watching these bland love-at-first-sight tales with 2-dimensional characters. It seems that Disney recognizes this is not a great trope they pulled from classic fairy tales, because they are clearly determined to abolish it nowadays. That doesn’t mean this film is unpleasant or hard to watch, though. I can see why Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs has stood the test of time, and could still be watched by children in the 2020s and be just as entertaining. It’s a well-constructed film with humor, romance, and a little horror. I just find, as I’ve grown up, I desire a bit more to get full enjoyment from my childhood favorites.
A Disney classic that is loved by all ages

Being the origin of many Disney tropes we've all been taking for granted for decades, and born out of the great depression, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs has elegant animation, timeless slapstick, and still some dramatic heft.

I love to watch and rate Disney movies, but I was not a fan of this one. I love the old animation on this, but the audio is older I didn't really see this as a kid but saw it later in life. I can't really say anything about this movie, just drags and is boring in my opinion and remember do not take a tainted apple from a old witch.

The movie has become so iconic and integral to the Disney "Brand" that discussions about its artistic merits have mostly been forgotten. That's a shame because this is the purest fairy tale adaption they ever did and the animation is truly stunning.

I found this movie to be quite interesting. Well, yes it is very emotionally driven, the story is lacking, but characters make up for it. At the end you want to see Snow White find her Prince Charming. The actual reason I would definitely recommend this movie, though, is the artwork. Recently there has been a drought of hand drawn films, so this was a breath of fresh air. Seeing the fine lines in every character, and the beautiful background really gave me an extra "umph" of appreciation for this film. Not to say that digitally animated movies don't take effort. This movie may be lacking on the story side so if you are looking for something along the lines of that skip this movie. Otherwise, it's a great flick.
Great for it's time, abit slow but still a childhood classic.

The most iconic and important animated movie of all time! To keep in mind how the movie was made back then in the 30s and what risks the company and Walt Disney himself committed to... It's just an awesome result and I think I've watched it more often than The Lion King from 1994 which I certainly watched over 50 times haha
A true milestone in movie history! Thank you, Walt!
Solid pacing, beautiful music, loveable characters--this film is the debut other studios should dream for.

'Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs' never fails to impress when I rewatch it, the animation is simply incredible given it was released in 1937.

Admittedly, it doesn't all hold up to an outstanding degree nowadays. The dwarfs still look fantastic, but Snow White herself and the world itself don't quite look exquisite; Snow White is rather dull, especially her facial expressions. I still have massive respect for those who created this though, obviously.

The voice cast, as was usual in the early decades of Disney, are a little forgettable. Adriana Caselotti (White) and Lucille La Verne (Queen) do fine jobs, though it's Pinto Colvig who is most memorable as Grumpy.

The premise is a pretty light too, with the main saviour hardly featuring and the antagonist disappearing for relatively large portions. Nonetheless, it's a great film to watch with family as Disney's first production is good fun - the music plays a huge part in that regard.
Phenomenal animation for its time. Everyone can remember singing along to the seven dwarves songs.

I think it so amazing it lets you know that jealousy and murder are never good to feel within you and that good always triumphs. The seven dwarfs are so funny. its a fairytale with romance and a happy ending.

While outdated by modern standards, Snow White manages to charm and delight its viewers with its charismatic lead, wickedly antagonizing villain, and strong supporting cast of characters. Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs is not only the start of The Disney Empire, it's also a very important piece of history as it's the pioneer of color animation feature films.
An incredibly impressive movie especially for it's time.
Sweet memories of a long-lost innocence

The Classic that started it all. Only Over shadowed by later classics, with more memorable and complex villains catcher tunes (Though Heigh-Ho is legendary I grant you) and more interesting Princesses -and Princes too. But it is a delight. The animation beautiful and sweet yet creepy when required. It still stands up today and probably will against the inevitable live action remake too.
As they say, they dont make them like this anymore, really amazing animation.
This was the Oldest Movie i had ever saw in my entire life
For the first Disney Animation movie, it's a very good one! It's not only a movie for kids, but is able to give an adult chills.

A true classic! The film that launched Disney and made it a true success, this film is incredible at being a true accomplishment of that time. With great animation, a sweet story, some laughs, and some darker moments, Snow White is a true classic and a must-watch for anyone.

A landmark in film, as the first full length animated film Snow White does also feature memorable characters, great music, a timeless fairy tale feel . It sets a true standard for Disney's long legacy.
The story may be a little thin but the songs remain catchy and the detail in the animation & backgrounds put some of todayâ(TM)s movies to shame. This is still a treat after all these years.

Though I feel people praise this one a little too much, some regarding it as the greatest animated film ever made simply because it was the first one, it still is a work of art. The dwarfs are one of the strongest parts of the film. While I love all of them and they're all drawn so distinctively(which I get credit given they are all the same height and have similar clothing patterns), there is one dwarf I feel does not get enough screentime: Sleepy. His lines are only once in awhile in the film, and I feel he deserved as much attention. Then again, what can a character say when he's asleep most of the time. The emotion has really been pushed high in this one for me, which is the other thing I find incredibly strong in this movie. If there's one Disney film that can make me cry, it's the last five minutes of the movie. Not any other Disney film besides Old Yeller and Snow White have made me cry. The scene where the dwarfs are gathered around lifeless Snow White and the depressed drawing expressions on them is something I'll never forget. The Prince does not have an interesting character, but he does have a great singing voice. The Queen is not one of the best Disney villains, nor does she have a lot of character, but that immediately changes when she turns into an old witch. At that point, it really grabbed my interest, and I was amazed at how well they made her character quite menacing and disturbing. That's a well-drawn character I would not want to come across in real life. There's that softness given to the character's coloring in animation that makes them look very lively and believable. While I do think they could have drawn the faces of the normal humans better, I still can't imagine Snow White being 14 and more of 16 or 17 instead. They make up for this though with the animation on the dwarfs, which, by the way, I love the animation on Grumpy. I admire how they all have different walks, and Grumpy's walk(along with Dopey's) are memorably distinctive. That small chewing animation on Grumpy when he walks with irritation is a small touch of detail that makes me understand the character he is without having to even listen to him talk. Some of the scenes that are personal favorites are from when the hunter is getting ready to try and kill Snow White, but fails, all the way to the end of her running through the forest. Suspense is strong in the film, and it's really helped by the dark shadows and grim detail in the animal and tree animation in the forest. The score also helps with the tone of a situation, and it's especially strong with those suspenseful, dramatic scenes. Speaking of the score, the songs are great, even though I do think a couple of them like the washing song and dwarf dance song go on a bit too long. It also amazes me to think that the voice actor of Happy, Otis Harlan, may have the record for the oldest actor that ever worked for Disney. A great classic, not one of my favorites(in fact, I don't put in my top 10 favorite Disney films), but it's still emotionally and dramatically pleasing with some lovable personalities and a strong score.

3.5/4

The best, GREATEST animated musical movie ever made! With the best movie character ever portrayed: Lucille La Verne as Queen Grimhilde! Plus 2 of the best movie songs ever sung: Whistle While You Work and Some Day My Prince Will Come! And the best movie quote ever spoken: "Magic mirror on the wall, who is the fairest one of all?"

While it's music doesn't quite stand the test of time, the animation still looks great. The dwarfs are still super lovable too. However, the facial design and animations of Snow White herself are off and they make her face look really weird at times. The dwarfs and the evil queen, however, look great. I really like the designs of the dwarfs too. the dwarfs really just steal the show. Their personalities, their interactions, their humor, it's all great. The environments and creepy imagery look great, too. The plot is fairly basic, the princess is pretty generic, and the love story is possibly the most bare bones and basic of all the Disney canon, but with a likeable villain and some great comic relief in the dwarfs, it's still a really enjoyable flick.
This classic may not have well defined characters or story, but it makes up for it with beautiful animation, beautiful music, and a lot of charm.

It's a nostalgic movie when you remember your beautiful memories.

Back before Disney Animation Studios was creating offensive Jewish wolfs and propaganda against Germany, their first major picture was a commendable achievement in cinematic animation history. Because it was the first, set standards, and raked in that good good money.

Snow White and the Seven Dwarves officially marks the first instance in which the overtly cartoonish style they were known for in shorts became mixed with more realistic models that seemed to move and act on an entirely different plane. That is to say they did. They were animated apart from the other subjects and painted onto different cels, and it holds up as well as Dopey and Sneezy in a trenchcoat. This creates my biggest gripe with Disney's feature films, being an inconsistant artstyle that only creates visual turmoil onscreen. This is where it began, and since this was the start of many successful films following it, this is why it mostly didn't stop.

The first wave feminist angle has done this movie in easily, but an angle that I'm not sure has been realized as well is the religious one. It's barely there but it does come out in the writing, and creates an entirely different perspective on why this film isn't something I would want to show my hypothetical daughters.

Only one small scene shows it. After the dwarves fight over a pillow downstairs, Snow White is seen and heard praying upstairs to the night sky (this was before the star). She feels "blessed" for the kindness of the dwarves and "prays" for the realization of her romantic wishes, "amen". The dialogue is probably written without a thought in mind as popular America was and is overtly Christian. 

What follows right after is the temptation of the apple. What occurred before was a princess basically mothering a bunch of old men in a polite and proper fashion, undertaking the tasks of a housewife and being an all around flawless kind girl. Snow White is written as the perfect Madonna, and the minute she gives into a bit of her own desire, elements of the Eve story are impossible to ignore.

It is only her remaining beauty (two seasons of avoiding decay and somehow not losing the blush in her cheeks after her blood congeals and her pulse stops) that saves her in the end and allows her wishes to be granted. Of course her actions beforehand were accompaniment to her beauty, and it acts as the other male characters' memory of her, but in a story of competition between two women on how good they look it's obvious that the simple fairy tale just doesn't translate well when given Christian overtones. The original fairy tale has stronger comparisons to Roman mythology and the tale of Mercury, Apollo, and Chione.

Especially now when Disney (both man and studio)'s faults have been mostly realized, they only succeed in making the film more uncomfortable and bumpy to watch. The relationship of Snow White and the dwarves teeters on motherly love and their own attractions, Grumpy's sexism is extremely off putting and only serves to strengthen the film's own messages of a Madonna/Eve duality, and the "slave" in the magic mirror is modeled with common (though subtle) cartoon facial tropes of black men.

The main factors that have aged well are the senses of extremities in emotion during those scenes dedicated to it. Snow White surrounded by terrifying green eyes in the forest is fantastic emphasis on the realization of her murderous stepmother, the Queen's spell brewing and transformation sequences create great atmosphere, and even a couple of the dwarves' scenes devoted to padding are effective like the silly song or Snow White's story of romance. The rest of the padding is unfortunately quite sleep inducing (a VERY bad thing for this film especially), and it takes up dozens of minutes. This is a half-hour film stretched out to feature length.

The songs, now that I think about it, are quite underwhelming. It's only because they've existed for about a hundred years that we all remember them. And since Disney has had so much practice with animating charming things and making a happy atmosphere, those types of scenes come and go without much impact anymore.

Snow White is emotionally sound and an impressive start to cinematic animation. The thematics are far too simplistic for us to really get into, and a bit too flawed and outdated for kids nowadays. It's a classic that is easy to praise, but only to a certain point. Although no other major ones exist, this adaptation of the German fairy tale certainly isn't fairest in the land.

It's the first one, the game changer, Snow White is the must-see classic where it comes to old animated movies. Amazing characters and a super entertaining, beautiful and pleasant tale that will always by one of the best in the Walt Disney Company!

|It's an 8,9 out of 10|

Everything about Snow White is brilliant and nostalgic.  One of my favorite things in this film is the audio track.  The primitive technology of the time really shines thru in it's audio, but it's all great when listening to it.  The animation is top notch even to this day.  PIXAR does amazing work, but to watch all this hand-drawn animation is breath-taking.  This film was ground-breaking and ushered our world into the world of animation.

A masterpiece in the line of Disney animation
Nothing short of pure perfection.

The story doesn't have that much substance and the main character and her love interest are admittedly bland and arguably useless, but the songs are all a bunch of catchy earworms, the animation is way ahead of its time (especially by 1930s standards), the villain is pretty intimidating and badass, and the side characters are all lovable and memorable. A solid start for feature-length Disney animation and one of cinema history's biggest landmarks.

Disney's first feature animated film. It makes me think that when he made this movie, it wasn't his first, it felt like he'd been making movies like this for years. Saying that shows just how gorgeous the animation and the story is! An immediate classic as soon as it came out in 1937! Though the princess and Prince are a tad bland for my taste, but that's not what makes this movie beautiful! It's the magic that was put into this movie, thanks to this movie there is even more animated movies out there today! A true masterpiece! 4.5/5 from me!

Snow White and the seven dwarfs

This was a pretty great movie. It made me feel homey and young at heart once more but there were certain instances where I didn't quite appreciate it to its full potential.

Let's just say that times have changed and the comments made by Grumpy about women were a bit uncalled for to be honest. This, I feel, goes hand in hand with the dwarfs expecting Snow White to do all the housework and cooking. Women shouldn't have to do it all themselves. Men are required to help out too. But I understand that the movie was written this way because of the time period and that's how a lot of people did things and how many men thought things should be.

I also disliked the mannerisms of the queen/witch. She was very abusive and harsh. But again, I understand that that's the character.

I've also realized that due to the time period, Walt Disney didn't hire many women to work on his films and I wish he did because they are genius.

Overall, I'd give this film about a four stars. With all things considered, it was a pretty great film.

Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs is an absolute abomination! The film is by no means a good example of what a children's film ought to be. Snow White is the embodiment of girlish sweetness and kindness, exemplified in her love for the birds and the small animals of the woods. Like most other Disney princesses such as Cinderella and Belle, Snow White is just another young princess with red lips, white skin, a skinny body, and a beautiful face. Even the magic mirror describes her as the girl with "lips red as the rose, hair black as ebony, [and] skin white as snow". From the very beginning, there's a huge emphasis put on Snow White's beauty. She's the "fairest" of the land. In other words, she's the prettiest. Not only is she pretty, though. She cooks and cleans too! In Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs Disney created a stereotypical depiction of how they think women should behave. A good children's movie doesn't portray women in such a biased way. And since Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs is a children's movie, I simply can't endorse it.
Throughout the film, Snow White is really only a plot point. She doesn't think for herself. She doesn't really do anything. Well, I guess that's not true. She embodies the image of a perfect woman. For instance as soon as Snow White enters the little house in the middle of the forest she criticizes the fact that the people who love in it are untidy and dirty. She decides to clean up the house without even knowing who lives in it. And cleaning the house was actually a pleasant activity for her. She loved it! This film influences girls to believe that they too should too clean. Unbelievable.Also, throughout the entire movie, all Snow White does is think about her handsome prince whom she will marry one day.  But how many times does he appear in the film? He only appears twice. He's seen in the beginning and the end of the movie. Yet as the story goes, the prince ends up being the one who saves the day. He rescues Snow White from her apparent death. Snow White was rescued by her prince and therefore entered his life instead of creating her own. 
As a mother of two little girls, I personally believe that Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs would be a terrible influence on my daughters. I wouldn't allow for them to watch it. I professionally believe that Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs misses the most important element that every children's movie should have: a good lesson. For that reason, I give this film a very poor rating.
Save your children from being brainwashed, don't let them watch this film.
One of the best Disney films - the songs, the illustration. Genuinely charming.
The film that created an industry. Snow White and Mickey Mouse were the dominant building blocks of Disney's entire enterprise, and we're still reaping the rewards.

Is it perfect? No. The main character is somewhat boring and there are too many deus ex machinas to count. But the film is a landmark in everything else and remains of the finest achievements in film history thanks to classic music, detailed animation and a fantastic supporting cast.

The Disney film that started it all

I loved this movie 10 years ago, and I still do. Sure it isn't the same as animation is now, but let's face it, most animation nowadays isn't very good. I can name a plethora of reasons why I love this movie. The animation is beautiful, with one or two stiff movements, but have a heart, it is the first Disney animation. The songs are mind-blowing, as well as the gorgeous incidental music(music similar to Great Expectations, 1946) that hardly anybody has mentioned. My favourite is "Someday my Prince Will Come", I cry every time I hear it. The characters are legendary, and the writing is top notch. Who can forget those adorable dwarfs, who added such a lot to this movie. Snow White is the weakest character but I like her innocence very much, and about her singing voice...it sounds weak, but in real life it must have been strong, and let me explain why. The colouratura soprano Amelita Galli-Curci was given the praise "a beautiful and limpid voice" yet I heard it on cassette and it sounds quite quiet. It has nothing to do with the size of the voice, but the quality of the recording. The best character was the wicked queen, who had the most classic animation scene I have ever seen... when she turns into a hag, which freaked me out big time when I was about 9, like Malificent from "Sleeping Beauty." To me the Queen is probably one of the scariest Disney villains ever. The scene at Snow White's coffin was heart-rending, and it was the music that made it so. All in all, a beautiful, funny and touching movie, and I can't believe some people hated this. 10/10. Bethany Cox

The original.  So everybody knows the story: there's a beautiful girl who sparks the scorn of a jealous queen.  When sent to her execution in the forest, the tasked huntsman cannot perform the deed, so she retreats to the woods to seek shelter with seven dwarfs, living in the middle of nowhere.  If you ever have the chance to go to either Disney World or Disneyland, it isn't hard to get inspired to go back and revisit some of these relics from the past.  Having just rode the Seven Dwarfs Mine Train on my honeymoon, my wife and I (gotta fully adjust from referring to her as my fiancé) decided to sit down this month and watch the very first Disney movie, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.  Sure, there are elements to it that are dated, but this is still an achievement for the medium, especially when you consider that this got released in 1937.  This may just be the most influential animated movie of all time.  It paved the way for so many animated films, all of which owe a tip of their hat to this one here.  The family market is a lucrative demographic, and if you win them over, they will come back multiple times over, even if it means buying an updated, higher resolution package to products they already own whenever the vault gets opened.  With this film there is just so much craft to it that is readily visible, and you can easily tell just how much time and effort went into this; between the art and the design, Snow White is always a visual treat.  Now I will say that some of the songs don't hold up; there are a couple of numbers that Snow White has toward the beginning that I had forgotten even existed.  But there are two songs prominently featured here that are instant classics in "Whistle While You Work", and "Heigh-Ho".  Even though Doc is essentially Happy with spectacles, the character designs are very successful in giving everyone a whole lot of personality in a very brief amount of time.  From a storytelling standpoint, I have a couple of issues, namely that Prince Charming is kind of worthless; he's in the film for maybe 4 minutes, and he gets still gets to claim all the glory of being the man that comes to the rescue at the end?  Clearly, a sign of the times.  Also, the evil queen vs. Snow White storyline is the most compelling angle, but we spend the majority of our time in this cabin with these dwarfs; this is obviously to make it more family friendly, as all of these guys are wholly lovable, and I completely understand that.  All of that said, making criticisms against this feels completely like nitpicking, given what a firmly cemented classic this is.
The first ever Disney animated movie still holds up over 80 years later with impressive animation and a memorable story and memorable characters.

The influence this animated classic has had cannot be underestimated; the animation is still stunning, the characters are vivid, and the songs ("Heigh-Ho," "Someday My Prince Will Come," "Whistle While You Work") are still being sung today.  A classic on every level.
